uk.ac.ed.epcc.webapp.jdbc.expr

Interface FilterProvider<T,D>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - type of target
    D - type of data to compare against
    All Superinterfaces:
    Targetted<D>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IndexedSQLValue<T,I>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractSelfSQLValue, CompositeIndexedSQLValue, ConstExpression, ConstIndexedSQLValue, DurationFieldValue, IndexedFieldValue, SelfSQLValue, TimestampDateFieldExpression, TupleSelfSQLValue, TypeConverterSQLValue, TypeFilterProducerSQLValue

    public interface FilterProvider<T,D>
extends Targetted<D>
    An object that can attempt provide an explicit SQL filter for its property. Normally implemented by a Accessor or SQLValue This allows the object to be used to construct complex SQL filters without implementing SQLExpression. Some filters may still be impossible in which case an exception is thrown. Higher levels of the code might still be able to make a filter by introducing a non SQL filter. Note that a CannotFilterException implies no filtering is possible for example if the property used is not supported. A NoSQLFilterException implies that only an SQL filter is impossible. Throwing a NoSQLFilterException gives the same behaviour as not implementing the interface at all. Therefore this is the exception that should be thrown when the class is only unable to fulfil its contract. For example if a nested Accessor does not implement FilterProvider. If implemented by a SQLValue the returned filter should contain any required filter.
